initial_story:
Firefighters and police were seen outside the office of Mike Freer MP

Police are investigating a suspected arson attack at the office of North London Conservative MP Mike Freer.

A fire broke out at the rear of the North Finchley and Golders Green MP's constituency office at around 19:00 on Christmas Eve.

The Met Police confirmed it is investigating the fire.

Mr Freer told the BBC the fire happened at the rear of the premises and no one was in the building at the time of the incident.

He continued: "The police and fire brigade were on the scene in minutes and have been incredible in their response."

London Fire Brigade (LFB) confirmed the fire started in a shed outside the office before spreading to the rest of the building.

An LFB spokesperson said: "An external shed was destroyed by fire. Part of the first, second and third floors of the property were also damaged by the blaze."

In a statement, a Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: "The cause of the fire is under investigation as it is believed it may have been started deliberately. There have been no arrests."

Pictures posted on social media showed Metropolitan Police and LFB vehicles at the premises on Sunday evening.

Mr Freer has represented the North London constituency since 2010.

He is parliamentary under-secretary of state for courts and legal services, a junior role in the Ministry of Justice.

Pictures show the fire spread to an office inside the building
stories:
I was sitting in my office, typing away, when I heard a knock on the door. "Come in," I said, not looking up from my computer. A man walked in, and I immediately recognized him as the notorious crime boss, Joey "The Knife" Moretti.

"You're a tough one to track down," he said, a smirk on his face. "But I'm glad I found you."

"What do you want?" I asked, trying to keep my voice steady.

"I've got a job for you," he said. "A big one."

"I'm not interested," I said, turning back to my computer. "I'm a busy man."

"This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," he said. "And it pays well."

I turned to look at him. "What is it?"

"There's a warehouse full of drugs," he said. "And we need to destroy it."

I raised an eyebrow. "Why me?"

"Because you're the best," he said. "And I'm willing to pay top dollar for your services."

I sighed. "Fine. I'll do it."

"Good," he said. "Meet me at the warehouse at midnight. And bring your A-game."

I nodded, and he turned to leave. As he walked out the door, I couldn't help but feel a sense of dread wash over me. This was going to be a tough job. But I was up for the challenge.

"Come in," I called out, not looking up from my work. A man entered, and I immediately recognized him as the notorious crime boss, Joey "The Knife" Moretti.

"You're a tough one to track down," he said, his voice thick with menace. "But I'm glad I found you."

"What do you want?" I asked, trying to keep my voice steady.

"I've got a job for you," he said, a smirk playing on his lips. "A big one."

"I'm not interested," I said, turning back to my work. "I'm a busy man."

"This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," he said, taking a step closer to me. "And it pays well."

I sighed, knowing that I had to at least hear him out. "What is it?"

"There's a warehouse full of drugs," he said. "And we need to destroy it."

I raised an eyebrow. "You want me to destroy a warehouse full of drugs?"

"That's right," he said. "And we need you to do it tonight."

I hesitated, unsure of what to say. This was not the kind of job I was used to taking on, but the pay was too good to pass up.

"I'll do it," I said finally.

"Good," he said, turning to leave. "I'll meet you at the warehouse at midnight. And bring your A-game."

I watched him leave, feeling a sense of dread wash over me. This was not going to be easy, but I was determined to get the job done.
